description: From Middle English cryer, criour, from Old French crieor (Modern French crieur), derived from the verb crier. Synchronically analyzable as cry +â€Ž -er.

examples: Once again she had been stricken, beaten down, so violated that to give utterance to her feelings might have outshrilled all the criers in hell.

entries.meaning: An officer who proclaims the orders or directions of a court, or who gives public notice by loud proclamation, such as a town crier.
